poem:
**Black Dog**

A flicker beneath
bamboo shadows,
fur like ink,  
dances in morning dew.  
Eyes cradle the 
great flickering state—
unspoken redemption,
a low bark against  
the crumbling stone.  
Here,
in the periphery of empire,
the heart finds  
its untamed,  
paws traveling  
the path of second prizes.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Black Dog review – state-of-the-Chinese-nation thriller with feelgood furry antics This isn’t the first film to serve up redemption through a furry emissary – and it won’t be the last. Guan Hu’s Chinese drama-cum-western-cum-state-of-the-nation missive won Un Certain Regard at Cannes this year – but more importantly, its heavy canine quotient meant it also bagged the second prize in the festival’s Palm Dog award. Its heartwarming aspect comes framed with real grandeur, and a stark". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
